results.title: Bark canoe
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Shows the primitive methods of canoe manufacture employed by the Australian Aborigine. Illustrates the removal of bark from a tree in a single section, its shaping and testing, and finally the canoe’s use for fishing. Introduced by Bill Onus.

results.title: Shellfish gathering
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Migratory habits of inland Aborigines who go walkabout to the coast to collect shellfish at certain times of the year, to augment their diet. The husband walks ahead and carries his fire sticks in his hair. His wife goes into the rock pools and quickly fills the string bag which hangs from her shoulder; cooks the fish in their shells in the hot ash; water is poured over the fire to cool the shellfish before they are removed and eaten.

results.title: Boomerang (A)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Demonstrates how the aborigine crafts the boomerang. The diligent search for the exact right piece of wood, the burning off of the outer bark, the tedious, laborious whittling with a sharpended stone and the fashioning of the slight twist at each end to git it its unique quality of returning to its point of departure. Introduced by Bill Onus.

results.title: Mutton birds
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Aborigines gather eggs and hunt the mutton bird on small coastal islands. The birds are removed from their burrows, killed and plucked before being loaded onto bark floats to be carried through the surf back to the camp fire.

results.title: Walkabout
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
An Aboriginal man and his wife undertake a pilgrimage to the sacred place of the Rainbow Serpent, the controller of rain, water and life on earth. They are shown walking to the coast through an uninhabited land, clambering down cliffs to the ocean. The man carries spears and always walks ahead. Their way of life in tribal times is clearly shown in this brief sequence, as the man carries two spears and walks ahead of his wife.

results.title: Woman gathers food
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Alcheringa”.
To the women falls the task of collecting supplementary foods - such as witchetty grubs and yams. Use is made of a sharply pointed stick to dig under bark for grubs and to kill a lizard which wanders across their path; also to dig for yams. The daughter accompanies her mother on her daily walk and learns the art of food gathering.

results.title: Turtle hunt
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Alcheringa”
Shows how Australia’s Aborigines lived hundreds of years ago. Shows unique methods of locating and hunting turtles by wading into shallow pools and feeling for the hard shells with bare feet, grasping their necks by hand, and roasting in hot ashes.

results.title: Fishing
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Illustrates the fishing methods of the Australian Aborigine. They are shown fishing on a lake, using three-pronged spears from bark canoes. With Bill Onus.

results.title: Making a stone axe
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Shows how Australia’s Aborigine lived hundreds of years ago. Primitive methos of tool making require both skill and patience. By means of grinding stones, the stone axe is shaped to the desired form.

results.title: Emu hunt
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Hunting for the Australian Aborigine’s most prized form of food - the emu. Two men after finding eggs follow the spoor across the desert, with their spears held ready to catch their prey.
